text:
CHARLICE HURST: So I'm part of a
working group at the University

of Notre Dame that's developed
a framework and a tool,

an online tool,
that it's intended

to foster a conversation
and advocacy around what--
around just wages.

And we've come up with what
we consider to be a just wage,

based on Catholic Social
Teaching, which is very
supportive of workers rights.

We've identified
seven criteria that we

believe are necessary to be
able to say a wage is just.

An underneath each
of those criterion
there are several indicators.

And I can't go
through all of them

but there's several indicators
that define the criterion,

and they encompass
both conditions

that enable a just wage and
are enabled by a just wage.

So our tool is intended
to address the entire wage
spectrum.

So we look at excess pay, we
look at professionals pay.

But there's a concept
in Catholic Social

Teaching called, The
Preferential Option,
for the poor.

And it basically
just means that when

we assess systems and
try to effect change,
we prioritize poor people.

So our tool prioritizes
just wages for the poor.

And we think about what
should come out of it.

So nobody thinks of overlaps
between radical black feminism
and Catholicism.

But this is a quote from the
Combahee River Collective
Statement.

It's considered a
foundational document
in radical black feminism.

Combahee River, by
the way, is the site

where Harriet Tubman led a Union
Army that freed 750 slaves.

So it's clear that radical
black feminists, the women who

framed this statement, and
Catholics, or at least those

who embrace Catholic Social
Teaching, which is not

all Catholics, believe that
economically marginalized
people should be prioritized.

We as women could not attain
gender equality and less

economically marginalized
women attain gender inequality.

So as you all probably
know, equal pay day
was the other day.

And I'm always a little
salty on equal pay

day because I think it
leaves a lot of people out.

So we've gotten
better at highlighting

wage gaps, the differentials
for women of color,
for black women, Latino women.

We don't talk about men,
which is something--

that's what I usually think
about I'm upset about that.

Because black men's wage
gap, Latinx's men's wage gap,

they're just as large as the
wage gap for white women.

But thinking about the
preferential option

as equal pay day
came up this year,

got me also thinking
about whether we

prioritize the poor enough
in equal pay conversations.
So I started looking at that.

And I've always admired
catalysts for instance.

They do a lot of good work
around gender inequality
in the workplace.

When I looked at their
website, searched for poverty,

and I saw very
little about poverty.

And there was
nothing about poverty
in the context of equal pay.

There was a toolkit for
attaining equal pay in finance.

And catalyst board
includes a number

of people who are
executives at companies

that have lots of
low wage workers,

often predominantly
in female jobs.

Likewise, leanin.org
has a page on equal pay

that does not mention poverty
and actually highlights

that college educated women
face a bigger gap, which

to me implicitly sidelines,
draws attention away

from lower paid women even
though whatever level of wage

gap they have is likely
to impact them more than
higher paid women's wage gap.

So [? Maureen ?] earlier,
mentioned that the fight for 15
and how $15 is still not enough.

And she talked about
the living wage.

But I want to challenge us in
thinking about the living wage.

Because the living
wage only accounts
for the absolute basics.
Oh, my god!

So emergency is major health
costs, so on, so forth
are not included.

So it's like we don't believe
that people who are poor

are deserving of the same
level of comfort and security
that we have.

So thinking about what
it means to prioritize

the poor means that we look
at the living wage and say,
this is not enough.

We want gender equality and this
is not going to get us there.

So I'm not saying
that we shouldn't
advocate for higher paid women.

Obviously we should, but if we
have limited advocacy resources

and we have to
prioritize someone,

why put the most vulnerable
people on the back burner.

There are many
more low paid women
than there are high paid women.

So we're going to say that we're
doing feminist equal pay work,
we prioritize poor people.
So just some thoughts.
[APPLAUSE]
